item.title: Mexico City metro overpass collapse kills 23
item.description: Several train carriages plunged to the ground when an elevated metro line collapsed.

item.title: India passes 20 million cases amid oxygen shortage
item.description: Officials say infections are slowing, but erratic testing and under-reporting cast doubt on their claims.

item.title: IPL suspended after rise in Covid-19 cases among players
item.description: The Indian Premier League is suspended after an increase in coronavirus cases among players.

item.title: Bill and Melinda Gates divorce after 27 years of marriage
item.description: The billionaire couple, who jointly run a charity organisation, say they can no longer "grow together".

item.title: Abbie Quinnen reveals 'horrible' Instagram abuse over burns
item.description: Abbie Quinnen says trolls targeted her after she suffered burns when a social media stunt went wrong.

item.title: Marriage certificate to include mothers' names in England and Wales
item.description: Both parents, not just the father, will now be named on marriage certificates in England and Wales.

item.title: G7: Foreign ministers to discuss rising threats at London summit
item.description: UK Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab will lead the first face-to-face talks in more than two years.

item.title: Gender recognition certificate cost cut to £5
item.description: Ministers pledged in September to slash the application fee after deciding against wider reforms.

item.title: PCSO Julia James: Candlelight vigil a week on from her death
item.description: Julia James's daughter has asked people to pay their respects to her from their doorsteps.

item.title: Pandora says laboratory-made diamonds are forever
item.description: The world's biggest jeweller says it will no longer use mined diamonds in a bid to become more sustainable.

item.title: Teens, tech and mental health: Oxford study finds no link
item.description: The Oxford study used data from more than 430,000 young people, gathered over 28 years.

item.title: Local elections: What would England's teens vote for if they could?
item.description: Climate change, mental health and the arts: what teenagers aged 16-17 would vote for.

item.title: The Papers: 'Wish EU were here' and holiday spots 'to reopen'
item.description: Tuesday's front pages focus on the prospect of Britons being able to travel abroad this summer.

item.title: Microchip shortage: Inside a factory racing to meet demand
item.description: Katie Silver tours a microchip factory in Singapore racing to meet demand amid a global shortage.

item.title: How rising sea levels are threatening my home
item.description: Hereiti, 17, lives on Rarotonga, the largest of the Cook Islands in the South Pacific Ocean.

item.title: Stock cubes help runner smash record on 212-mile route
item.description: Anna Rutherford beat the Southern Upland Way record by 17 hours, just nine months after giving birth.

item.title: Bill and Melinda Gates: A life in pictures
item.description: Images of the couple, who set up the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation in 2000, after they announce their divorce.

item.title: Iraq bans terror prank TV shows
item.description: The two shows sparked outrage after using fake suicide vests and staging kidnappings.

item.title: Canadian sign war captivates the internet
item.description: For the past week, businesses in a Canadian town have been embroiled in a war of words via signs.

item.title: Hospital Covid team plant trees to fight climate change
item.description: Staff from a Cardiff intensive care unit are offsetting the environmental impact of treating patients.

item.title: Covid: Music fans take part in pilot concert with Blossoms
item.description: Five-thousand music fans attend a pilot concert held in a big top in Liverpool.

item.title: Simon Stevens: How heavy hitter changed the NHS
item.description: Sir Simon Stevens has been called the NHS's most significant figure since its founder, Aneurin Bevan.

item.title: Dove Cameron: Why the former Disney star is one to watch in 2021
item.description: With two TV shows, a movie and a pop career in the making, the former Disney star is one to watch.

item.title: Covid: Lockdown loneliness could leave people 'stuck', charity warns
item.description: Amid a rise in reports of loneliness, some people fear a struggle to re-integrate as lockdown eases.

item.title: Food giants respond to worries over packaging
item.description: The phasing out of single-use plastics gathers pace with big companies adopting alternatives.

item.title: Battle of wits: Antiguans revel in ancient board game
item.description: Warri is a board game popular in Antigua which traces its origins back to Africa.

item.title: The rise of India's 'Covid quack'
item.description: An anti-vaccine doctor falsely claims to be able to cure coronavirus, diabetes and Aids through diet alone

item.title: Five Eyes: Is the alliance in trouble over China?
item.description: The Five Eyes intelligence alliance has expanded into politics but faces a split in dealing with Beijing.

item.title: India Covid: Delhi hospitals plead for oxygen as more patients die
item.description: Desperate messages continued on Sunday night as Delhi's oxygen crisis shows no signs of abating.

item.title: Coronavirus: Why some mosques are closed to women during Ramadan
item.description: Ramadan is marked by Muslims worldwide - but some UK mosques aren't letting women in.

item.title: Covid: Packed pilot festival brings the good times back - for one night
item.description: Blossoms play to 5,000 fans in Liverpool to help gather research for this summer's festival season.

item.title: Why can't Google get a grip on rip-off ads?
item.description: Shyster websites topped the search results every time during a 12-month BBC investigation.

item.title: A £455m debt and the ESL: Man Utd protests explained
item.description: Protests at Manchester United's Old Trafford ground came just weeks after European Super League plans were thwarted - but emotions have been simmering for 16 years.

item.title: Four-time world champion Selby will not chase records of snooker's 'all-time greats'
item.description: Mark Selby says he is not preoccupied with records set by the game's "all-time greats" after winning a fourth World Championship on Monday.

item.title: 'We won't give up on Champions League dream' - Antonio double gives West Ham win at Burnley
item.description: Michail Antonio scores twice as West Ham come from behind to defeat Burnley and maintain their pursuit of a top-four finish.

item.title: 'We need a magic miracle and fairy dust' - West Brom rue missed chances in draw with Wolves
item.description: West Brom boss Sam Allardyce says the Baggies need a "magic miracle and fairy dust" to stay in the Premier League after drawing with Wolves.

item.title: Fight Talk: 'Dead in the water' to 'this fight is on' - the Anthony Joshua v Tyson Fury saga continues
item.description: Bob Arum says it is "dead in the water" but Eddie Hearn says "this fight is on". The Anthony Joshua v Tyson Fury saga continues, plus more boxing news and reaction.

item.title: Who takes his side to 'another level' - and made Garth Crooks' team of the week?
item.description: Who takes his side to another level? Who has been a credit to the Premier League? Find out in Garth Crooks' team of the week.

item.title: World Snooker Championship: Mark Selby beats Shaun Murphy in final - best shots
item.description: Watch the best shots as Mark Selby beats Shaun Murphy to win his fourth World Snooker Championship title.

item.title: Scottish election 2021: Does Scotland's future lie in or out of the Union?
item.description: BBC Scotland's James Cook hears from those both for and against another referendum on independence.

item.title: Scottish election 2021: Who should I vote for? Compare party policies
item.description: Compare where the parties stand on key issues - from Covid-19 and the NHS to education and the environment.

item.title: Election 2021: How do I vote and why could results take longer?
item.description: About 48 million people will be able to vote in a series of elections on Thursday 6 May.

item.title: 2021 elections: A simple guide to the Scottish, Welsh and local elections
item.description: A bumper crop of elections are being held on 6 May across England, Scotland and Wales.

item.title: 2021 elections: What elections can I vote in this year?
item.description: National elections in Scotland and Wales and local elections in England are scheduled for 6 May 2021.

item.title: Scottish election 2021: Has the campaign changed voters' minds?
item.description: Politicians have spent the last six weeks trying to persuade people to vote for them - but has it worked?

item.title: Shaun Bailey: 'Politics isn't scary when you've seen stabbings'
item.description: Shaun Bailey says having grown up poor and been homeless in London, politics does not phase him.

item.title: Elections 2021: Why a lack of buses is a key issue for voters
item.description: Infrequent buses and cancelled services - why public transport is a vital topic for young voters.

item.title: When can I holiday abroad and where is on the green and red lists?
item.description: A so-called "green list" of countries is being drawn up where quarantine won't be required when you return to the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions continue to be relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules have been eased further across the UK - more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Covid: Restaurants and pubs are reopening, but what are the rules?
item.description: Northern Ireland follows England, Scotland and Wales in allowing venues to reopen outdoors.

item.title: When does the stamp duty holiday in England and Northern Ireland end?
item.description: What is the stamp duty holiday and when will it finish?

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Rare blood clots - what you need to know
item.description: We take a look at why these unusual clots happen and when they occur.

item.title: Covid: Is Europe lifting lockdown restrictions?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People 40 or over in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.
